23719.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, khippatta refers to the quality of being swift, highlighting the superiority of a practice that is both pleasant and quick.
23719.sutta_1: Tatra, bhante, yāyaṁ paṭipadā sukhā khippābhiññā, ayaṁ pana, bhante, paṭipadā ubhayeneva paṇītā akkhāyati sukhattā ca khippattā ca.
23719.example_1: But the pleasant practice with swift insight is said to be superior both ways: because it’s pleasant and because it’s swift.

49511.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, bhassasamācāra refers to the Buddha's unsurpassable way of teaching proper verbal conduct.
49511.sutta_1: Aparaṁ pana, bhante, etadānuttariyaṁ, yathā bhagavā dhammaṁ deseti bhassasamācāre.
49511.example_1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches behavior in speech is unsurpassable.

53063.meaning_1: connected to false speech; related to lying
53063.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term describes speech that is ethically problematic due to its connection with falsehood.
53063.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco na ceva musāvādupasañhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati na ca vebhūtiyaṁ na ca pesuṇiyaṁ na ca sārambhajaṁ jayāpekkho;
53063.example_1: It’s when someone doesn’t use speech that’s connected with lying, or divisive, or backbiting, or aggressively trying to win.

70391.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, vebhūtiyaṁ is listed alongside other types of harmful speech (musāvāda, pesuṇiya, sārambhaja), showing it refers to speech that divides people.
70391.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco na ceva musāvādupasañhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati na ca vebhūtiyaṁ na ca pesuṇiyaṁ na ca sārambhajaṁ jayāpekkho;
70391.example_1: It’s when someone doesn’t use speech that’s connected with lying, or divisive, or backbiting, or aggressively trying to win.

28008.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, jayāpekkho describes speech that is aggressively trying to win arguments or debates.
28008.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco na ceva musāvādupasañhitaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati na ca vebhūtiyaṁ na ca pesuṇiyaṁ na ca sārambhajaṁ jayāpekkho;
28008.example_1: It’s when someone doesn’t use speech that’s connected with lying, or divisive, or backbiting, or aggressively trying to win.

47088.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The compound refers specifically to the ethical conduct or behavior of a person, as taught by the Buddha in the contextual sentence from DN 28.
47088.sutta_1: Aparaṁ pana, bhante, etadānuttariyaṁ, yathā bhagavā dhammaṁ deseti purisasīlasamācāre.
47088.example_1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches a person’s ethical behavior is unsurpassable.

22717.meaning_1: deceiver; cheat; fraud; one who creates false impressions
22717.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, kuhaka is contrasted with qualities like honesty and faithfulness, showing it refers to someone who engages in deception.
22717.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
22717.example_1: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.

37056.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the word describes someone who doesn't use material things to chase after other material things (lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako).
37056.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
37056.example_1: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.

37054.meaning_1: who desires; who seeks; who wishes to get
37054.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the term appears in a description of virtuous qualities, contrasting with greed and manipulative behavior. The meaning aligns with seeking or desiring, but in a negative context of wanting to gain material benefits.
37054.example_1: aparaṃ pana, bhante, etadānuttariyaṃ, yathā bhagavā dhammaṃ deseti purisasīlasamācāre. idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanako [jijigiṃsanako, nijigiṃsitā], indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca. etadānuttariyaṃ, bhante, purisasīlasamācāre.

59123.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, samakārī describes someone who acts fairly and impartially, without favoritism or bias, as part of a list of virtuous qualities.
59123.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
59123.example_1: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.

28163.meaning_1: devoted to the practice of wakefulness
28163.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term describes someone who is dedicated to maintaining wakefulness and alertness as part of their spiritual practice, along with other qualities like guarding the sense doors and being energetic.
28163.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
28163.example_1: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.

2013.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, atandī is used to describe someone who is dedicated to wakefulness and energetic, emphasizing their lack of laziness.
2013.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
2013.example_1: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.

50933.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, matimā (nom.sg. of matimant) describes someone with good mental qualities including thoughtfulness and insight, along with other virtues like mindfulness and eloquence.
50933.sutta_1: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
50933.example_1: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.

42950.meaning_1: knowledge of other people's level of liberation
42950.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
This term refers to one of the Buddha's special knowledges - the ability to discern others' spiritual attainments and levels of liberation.
42950.sutta_1: Aparaṁ pana, bhante, etadānuttariyaṁ, yathā bhagavā dhammaṁ deseti parapuggalavimuttiñāṇe.
42950.example_1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the knowledge and freedom of other individuals is unsurpassable.

61843.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The aorist form saṃvaṭṭi is used in the context of cosmic contraction, paired with vivaṭṭi (expansion) to describe the cyclical nature of the universe.
61843.sutta_1: ‘atītampāhaṁ addhānaṁ jānāmi—saṁvaṭṭi vā loko vivaṭṭi vāti.
61843.example_1: ‘I know that in the past the cosmos expanded or contracted.

69513.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, vivaṭṭi contrasts with saṁvaṭṭi, referring to the cosmic contraction phase.
69513.sutta_1: ‘atītampāhaṁ addhānaṁ jānāmi—saṁvaṭṭi vā loko vivaṭṭi vāti.
69513.example_1: ‘I know that in the past the cosmos expanded or contracted.

7921.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this describes past rebirths in various states of existence (formed, formless, etc.)
7921.sutta_1: Api ca yasmiṁ yasmiṁ attabhāve abhinivuṭṭhapubbo hoti yadi vā rūpīsu yadi vā arūpīsu yadi vā saññīsu yadi vā asaññīsu yadi vā nevasaññīnāsaññīsu.
7921.example_1: Still, no matter what incarnation they have previously been reborn in—whether formed or formless or percipient or non-percipient or neither percipient nor non-percipient—

7923.meaning_1: having previously dwelt in; formerly inhabited
7923.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The word describes beings who have previously inhabited various states of existence, as mentioned in the DN28 context discussing recollection of past lives.
7923.example_1: santi, bhante, devā [sattā], yesaṃ na sakkā gaṇanāya vā saṅkhānena vā āyu saṅkhātuṃ. api ca, yasmiṃ yasmiṃ attabhāve abhinivuṭṭhapubbo [abhinivutthapubbo] hoti yadi vā rūpīsu yadi vā arūpīsu yadi vā saññīsu yadi vā asaññīsu yadi vā nevasaññīnāsaññīsu. iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.

56251.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, saupadhikā describes psychic powers that are accompanied by defilements and attachments, making them ignoble (no ariyā).
56251.sutta_1: atthi, bhante, iddhi sāsavā saupadhikā, ‘no ariyā’ti vuccati.
56251.example_1: There are psychic powers that are accompanied by defilements and attachments, and are said to be ignoble.

4676.meaning_1: without attachment; free from clinging; not dependent on substratum
4676.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, it describes psychic powers (iddhi) that are free from attachments and defilements, emphasizing their noble (ariyā) nature.
4676.sutta_1: Atthi, bhante, iddhi anāsavā anupadhikā ‘ariyā’ti vuccati.
4676.example_1: And there are psychic powers that are free of defilements and attachments, and are said to be noble.

21069.meaning_1: devoted to indulgence in sense pleasure
21069.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term is used to describe what the Buddha does NOT practice, emphasizing his rejection of both hedonism and asceticism.
21069.sutta_1: Na ca, bhante, bhagavā kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogamanuyutto hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyutto dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ.
21069.example_1: The Buddha doesn’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And he doesn’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.

2450.meaning_1: devoted to the practice of self-mortification
2450.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence contrasts this term with indulgence in sensual pleasures, showing the Buddha's rejection of both extremes.
2450.sutta_1: Na ca, bhante, bhagavā kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogamanuyutto hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyutto dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ.
2450.example_1: The Buddha doesn’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And he doesn’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.

58294.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, santuṭṭhitā is used to describe one of the qualities of the Tathāgata, along with appicchatā (having few wishes) and sallekhatā (self-effacement). The term emphasizes the state of being content or satisfied.
58294.sutta_1: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante, tathāgatassa appicchatā santuṭṭhitā sallekhatā.
58294.example_1: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has so few wishes, such contentment, such self-effacement!

61222.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, sallekhatā is used to describe the Buddha's quality of self-effacement and contentment, highlighting his ascetic practice.
61222.sutta_1: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante, tathāgatassa appicchatā santuṭṭhitā sallekhatā.
61222.example_1: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has so few wishes, such contentment, such self-effacement!

38826.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows nevatta used in a negative construction (na + eva + atta) meaning "not even oneself", emphasizing the Tathāgata's humility despite his great powers.
38826.sutta_1: Yatra hi nāma tathāgato evaṁmahiddhiko evaṁmahānubhāvo, atha ca pana nevattānaṁ pātukarissati.
38826.example_1: For even though the Realized One has such power and might, he will not make a display of himself.

45915.meaning_1: the inspiring discourse; the delightful discourse
45915.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The Pāsādikasutta is the 29th sutta of the Dīgha Nikāya, known for its inspiring and delightful content.

70340.meaning_1: name of a Sakyan family clan
70340.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The word refers to a specific clan within the Sakyan people, as evidenced by the contextual sentence where the Buddha stays in their mango grove.
70340.sutta_1: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati vedhaññā nāma sakyā, tesaṁ ambavane pāsāde.
70340.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans in a stilt longhouse in a mango grove belonging to those Sakyans named Vedhaññā.
